Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: With only an hour left in the shift, they are still a few sales short of the weekly target.
Story:
My phone buzzed just as I was about to dial another number from my call list. It was almost midnight, and I was behind on my sales target—three more to go, and only an hour left in my shift. I hesitated, but when I saw it was Jamie, I answered. Her voice was shaky, barely more than a whisper, and I could hear her sobbing. She told me her father had just been rushed to the hospital. My heart twisted; Jamie had always been there for me, and now she needed me to listen, to comfort her, to be the friend she could lean on.

But as she spoke, my eyes darted to the clock and the list of potential customers on my screen. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: “We need those numbers tonight.” If I didn’t make those sales, I’d miss my bonus and maybe even face a warning. I tried to focus on Jamie’s words, but my mind kept drifting to the calls I still had to make. I wanted to be the friend she deserved, but the pressure to perform at work pressed down on me, making it hard to breathe.
